results.title: Lust and revenge
results.creator_credit: Illumination Films (AU), Paul Cox and Jane Ballantyne
results.brief_description: Georgina Oliphant commissions her friend Lily to create a sculpture for a new wing at the National Gallery. Her father sees it as an opportunity for a healthy tax deduction. Karl Heinz, who is chosen as the model for the sculpture, sees it as a chance to buy a cottage in Handover. His wife Celia, who is heavily involved in a New Age religious group, isn’t so thrilled. Everyone wants something but who will ultimately win? The film twists and turns towards its hilarious conclusion. Nominated for Best Director in the 1996 AFI Awards, “Lust and Revenge” is a biting satire on the arts world and the financial imperatives driving it. However, the most powerful element of the film is the development of the characters as they are drawn into this Machiavillian power game. Look out for some wonderful cameo roles, particularly from Wendy Hughes and John Hargreaves.

results.title: Lungs
results.creator_credit: Educational Media International, D Morgan and A K Lee
results.brief_description: Discusses the structure, function and mechanism of the lungs. The overall structure of the lungs and air passage is presented by means of a sheep dissection and a living lung is seen during a routine operationat a veterinary clinic. The movement of the diaphragm and ribs is clearly highlighted by X-ray.

results.title: Lunawanna kiss
results.creator_credit: James Middleton Films and James Middleton
results.brief_description: A Catholic boatman, living on a remote island off the south coast of Tasmania in 1931, falls in love with the Protestant lighthouse keeper’s daughter. Silent film with musical soundtrack composed by Franz Schubert with Christina Bush-Sigrist on violin, Sue Pickering on cello and Jody Heald on piano. Cast: Saul Darby, Lucy Gouldthorpe, Jim Higgins, Jane Byrne.

results.title: Luna, luna, luna
results.creator_credit: Francine Desbiens, ONF | NFB and Viviane Elnecave
results.brief_description: A child sleepwalks into the forest. A black vastness inhabited by night creatures throbs and chirps, croaks and gurgles. As she wades deeper into the shimmering night, the real forest and the imaginary one dissolve into each other. Apparitions and phantoms begin their nocturnal dance. The atmosphere becomes charged and witches come shrieking to life. When the fear of the night reaches its peak, the moon rises and the final lunacy begins. An animated film about a child’s reaction to the mysteries and magic of the night. Film without words. (Awards: Zagreb; Lausanne)

results.title: Lumsden
results.creator_credit: Tom Daly, ONF | NFB and Peter Raymont
results.brief_description: Lumsden, Saskatchewan, is a town of 850 citizens on a river called the Qu’Appelle. In the spring of 1974, the river doubled its volume and threatened to flood the town. The townspeople organized themselves and the whole province stood behind them. It is the story of an incredible battle against impossible odds.

results.title: Lumiere programme [Silent version]
results.brief_description: The first public film show in Great Britain was given at the Regent Street Polytechnic London, on February 20th, 1896, by the brothers August and Louis Lumiere. This film is a complete reprint of the programs shown on that occasion. It comprises the following subjects: Workers leaving the Lumiere factory; Baby at the lunch table; Demolition of a wall; Watering the gardener; Congress of Photographic Societies at Neuville-Sur-Saone, July 1895; Arrival of a train at Ciotat Station; A game of cards; A boat leaving harbour. None of these films is more than a single shot, without cutting or camera movement; their interest lay entirely in the novelty of the moving photograph.

results.title: Lumiere programme
results.brief_description: The first public film show in Great Britain was given at the Regent Street Polytechnic London, on February 20th, 1896, by the brothers August and Louis Lumiere. This film is a complete reprint of the programs shown on that occasion. It comprises the following subjects: Workers leaving the Lumiere factory; Baby at the lunch table; Demolition of a wall; Watering the gardener; Congress of Photographic Societies at Neuville-Sur-Saone, July 1895; Arrival of a train at Ciotat Station; A game of cards; A boat leaving harbour. None of these films is more than a single shot, without cutting or camera movement; their interest lay entirely in the novelty of the moving photograph. This version includes a piano accompaniment and narration which was added in 1956.

results.title: Lumiere
results.brief_description:
Compilation film based on reels shot by the brothers Lumiere and their staff. It contains street scenes and public events: cruise on the Seine, the lift of the Eiffel Tower, a visit of Czar Nicholas II to Paris in 1896. Those scenes are the earliest sights of Paris ever recorded on film

Credits: Producer, Pierre Braunberger ; director, Marc Allegret ; music, Henri Sauguet.

results.title: Lumaaq: an Eskimo legend [French version] = Lumaaq: une legende esquimo
results.creator_credit: Pierre Moretti, ONF | NFB and Co Hoedeman
results.brief_description: Lumaaq tells the story of a legend widely believed by the Povungnituk Innuit. The artist’s drawings are transferred to paper, cut out and animated under the camera. The result is Innuit prints in action. Dialogue, music and artwork make this film a total cultural transplant. Sound film without commentary.
